web_research.query: What are winning approaches for text classification with meta features on Kaggle competitions?
web_research.finding:
Winning solutions for text‑classification contests on Kaggle often treat the problem as a hybrid of classic NLP and tabular learning: the raw text is turned into high‑dimensional sparse vectors (e.g., TF‑IDF or hashed n‑grams) and then concatenated with engineered “meta” features such as text length, number of punctuation marks, presence of URLs, or domain‑specific identifiers. A common recipe is to clean the posts, compute a TF‑IDF matrix, and append a handful of these meta columns before feeding the data to a linear model trained in a one‑vs‑rest fashion with stochastic gradient descent (SGD), which scales well to millions of features and can be tuned with simple regularisation tricks ([Kaggle discussion](https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/facebook-recruiting-iii-keyword-extraction/writeups/barisumog-share-your-approach)).  

In addition to linear models, many top teams use an online‑learning baseline such as logistic regression with the “hash trick” and an adaptive learning rate; t
